title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: members, contributors, leaders pledge make participation community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, visible invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity expression, level experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, caste, color, religion, sexual identity orientation. pledge act interact ways contribute open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, healthy community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others’ private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders responsible clarifying enforcing standards acceptable behavior take appropriate fair corrective action response behavior deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful. Community leaders right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, communicate reasons moderation decisions appropriate.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within community spaces, also applies individual officially representing community public spaces. Examples representing community include using official e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported community leaders responsible enforcement charlotte.lambert@univ-lr.fr. complaints reviewed investigated promptly fairly. community leaders obligated respect privacy security reporter incident.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders follow Community Impact Guidelines determining consequences action deem violation Code Conduct:

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Use inappropriate language behavior deemed unprofessional unwelcome community. Consequence: private, written warning community leaders, providing clarity around nature violation explanation behavior inappropriate. public apology may requested.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: violation single incident series actions. Consequence: warning consequences continued behavior. interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, specified period time. includes avoiding interactions community spaces well external channels like social media. Violating terms may lead temporary permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: serious violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior. Consequence: temporary ban sort interaction public communication community specified period time. public private interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, allowed period. Violating terms may lead permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Demonstrating pattern violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior, harassment individual, aggression toward disparagement classes individuals. Consequence: permanent ban sort public interaction within community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct adapted Contributor Covenant, version 2.1, available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/2/1/code_of_conduct.html. Community Impact Guidelines inspired [Mozilla’s code conduct enforcement ladder][https://github.com/mozilla/inclusion]. answers common questions code conduct, see FAQ https://www.contributor-covenant.org/faq. Translations available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/translations.

title: Energyscape of top predator
text: estimate energyscape prey biomass consumption, first estimate energyscape (spatialised energetic need population) marine predator species (either cetacean, seabirds, loggerhead turtles, sunfish, sharks, tunas swordfish) abundance map body mass distribution, well sea surface temperature (fish ). Second, estimate daily ration consumed given prey group single predator individual corresponding biomass consumed total population. done bio_cons_est(), runs single estimation, drawing one sample provided distribution (body mass, abundance map, SST).
code: result <- bio_cons_est(predator_group = "Cetacean",              predator_name = "TURTRU",               prey_taxonomic_level = "Taxonomic_group",               prey_group = "Cephalopoda",              diet = diet,               assimilation_rate = 0.8,              n_days = 30+31+31,              predator_weight = weight,               abundance_map = species_abundance,               temperature_map = sst,              beta = beta) # not used for fishes and seabirds

title: Energyscape of top predator
text: obtain final estimations, embed function Monte Carlo simulation runs many times required obtain reliable estimate. number simulation set 1000 default can changed user.
code: # test mc_simulation() with one prey level TURTRU_result <- mc_simulation(predator_name = "TURTRU",                                 predator_group = "Cetacean",              map_coordinates = map_coords,              prey_taxonomic_level = "Taxonomic_group",               diet = diet |> subset(Taxonomic_group == "Cephalopoda"),               assimilation_rate = 0.8,              n_days = 30+31+31,              predator_weight = weight,               abundance_map = species_abundance,               temperature_map = sst, # not used for cetaceans and seabirds              beta = beta)  # test mc_simulation() with 2 prey levels TURTRU_result <- mc_simulation(predator_name = "TURTRU",                                 predator_group = "Cetacean",              map_coordinates = map_coords,              prey_taxonomic_level = "Taxonomic_group",               diet = diet,               assimilation_rate = 0.8,              n_days = 30+31+31,              predator_weight = weight,               abundance_map = species_abundance,               temperature_map = sst, # not used for cetaceans and seabirds              beta = beta) #> Computing Teleost for TURTRU #> Computing Cephalopoda for TURTRU #> Wrapping up  # plot results ggplot2::ggplot(TURTRU_result$Conso) +     ggplot2::geom_pointrange(ggplot2::aes(y = Prey_category, x = mean, xmin = L10, xmax = U90)) ggplot2::ggplot(TURTRU_result$Energyscape) +   ggplot2::geom_tile(ggplot2::aes(x = x, y = y, fill = Energyscape_mean))

what: energyscapes: Estimating top predator energyscapes and biomass consumption
text: goal energyscapes estimate field metabolic rate marine top predator species. Combining FMR body mass distribution data, abundance SST allometric relationships, package permits estimating total energyscape species, spatialised energetic needs total population. Furthermore, energyscape can used combination diet composition prey energy content information estimate total biomass prey necessary top predator population sustain needs. package uses Monte Carlo simulations build posterior distributions parameters propagate uncertainty various sources throughout analyses final estimations.

previous_headings: energyscapes: Estimating top predator energyscapes and biomass consumption
text: package contains example data, can loaded : data represents various elements needed analyses particular case bottlenose dolphin Mediterranean Sea: distribution body mass population, map abundance, map SST (useful fish species), diet composition, coordinates map distribution beta parameter used allometric equation.
code: library(energyscapes) library(ggplot2) library(viridis) #> Loading required package: viridisLite data(list = c("diet", "species_abundance", "sst", "weight", "map_coords", "beta")) plot(density(weight), main = "Body mass distribution in the population") plot(density(beta), main = "cost of living") ggplot(species_abundance) +    geom_tile(aes(x = x, y = y, fill = mean)) +   scale_fill_viridis(option = "H") ggplot(sst) +    geom_tile(aes(x = x, y = y, fill = mean)) +   scale_fill_viridis(option = "H") str(diet) # see ?diet for the detail about table structure #> tibble [30 × 14] (S3: tbl_df/tbl/data.frame) #>  $ Predator_key              : chr [1:30] "TURTRU" "TURTRU" "TURTRU" "TURTRU" ... #>  $ Latin_name                : chr [1:30] "Boops boops" "Pagellus sp" "Dentex dentex" "Pagellus erythrinus" ... #>  $ pW                        : num [1:30] 1.7 3.4 2.6 7.2 3.2 2.4 0.4 0.7 0.3 0.1 ... #>  $ pW_uncertainty            : logi [1:30] NA NA NA NA NA NA ... #>  $ Source.x                  : chr [1:30] "Queiros et al 2018 MEPS" "Queiros et al 2018 MEPS" "Queiros et al 2018 MEPS" "Queiros et al 2018 MEPS" ... #>  $ Common_name               : chr [1:30] "Bogue" "Seabream unknown" "Common dentex" "Common pandora" ... #>  $ Energy_content            : num [1:30] 8 9.4 7.6 9.4 9.4 8.1 8.1 10.2 8.5 6.2 ... #>  $ Energy_content_uncertainty: logi [1:30] NA NA NA NA NA NA ... #>  $ Estimate_level            : chr [1:30] "species" "genus" "family" "genus" ... #>  $ Family                    : chr [1:30] "Sparidae" "Sparidae" "Sparidae" "Sparidae" ... #>  $ Taxonomic_group           : chr [1:30] "Teleost" "Teleost" "Teleost" "Teleost" ... #>  $ Functional_group          : chr [1:30] "Demersal fish" "Pelagic fish" "Pelagic fish" "Pelagic fish" ... #>  $ Source.y                  : chr [1:30] "Queiros et al 2018 MEPS" "Queiros et al 2018 MEPS" "Queiros et al 2018 MEPS" "Queiros et al 2018 MEPS" ... #>  $ ...10                     : chr [1:30] NA NA NA NA ...

previous_headings: energyscapes: Estimating top predator energyscapes and biomass consumption
text: data, use main function package (mc_simulation()) run Monte Carlo simulations estimate energyscape biomass consumptions: function returns bunch objects: Maps FMR energyscape, also spatialised daily ration (expressed proportion body mass) spatialised biomass consumption. Tables summarising daily ration (one individual, raw proportion body mass) total consumption, per prey category. estimated values comes mean, standard deviation, lower 10% upper 90% posterior distribution Monte Carlo simulation. example estimated consumption: code automated diet items can sorted taxonomy (prey_taxonomic_level = “Taxonomic_group”), functional groups (prey_taxonomic_level = “Functional_group”), family (prey_taxonomic_level = “Family”) relevant grouping variable (prey_taxonomic_level must column diet dataframe). also created custom color palette used plotting results functions. palette matches EcoScope project graphic templates ggplot2 friendly (scale_fill_ecoscope scale_color_ecoscope).
code: # test mc_simulation() with 2 prey levels TURTRU_result <- mc_simulation(predator_name = "TURTRU",                                 predator_group = "Cetacean",              map_coordinates = map_coords,              prey_taxonomic_level = "Taxonomic_group",               diet = diet,               assimilation_rate = 0.8,              n_days = 30+31+31,              predator_weight = weight,               abundance_map = species_abundance,               temperature_map = sst, # not used for cetaceans and seabirds              beta = beta) #> Computing Teleost for TURTRU #> Computing Cephalopoda for TURTRU #> Wrapping up str(TURTRU_result, max.level = 1) #> List of 8 #>  $ FMR_map              :'data.frame':   5720 obs. of  8 variables: #>  $ Energyscape          :'data.frame':   5720 obs. of  12 variables: #>  $ DailyRation          :'data.frame':   2 obs. of  6 variables: #>  $ DailyRationPropBM    :'data.frame':   2 obs. of  6 variables: #>  $ Conso                :'data.frame':   2 obs. of  6 variables: #>  $ DailyRation_map      :'data.frame':   11440 obs. of  8 variables: #>  $ DailyRationPropBM_map:'data.frame':   11440 obs. of  8 variables: #>  $ Conso_map            :'data.frame':   11440 obs. of  8 variables: #> Computing Demersal fish for TURTRU #> Computing Pelagic fish for TURTRU #> Computing Pelagic cephalopod for TURTRU #> Computing Benthic cephalopod for TURTRU #> Wrapping up

title: Toolbox For Energyscape Analyses
text: goal energyscapes estimate field metabolic rate marine top predator species. Combining FMR body mass distribution data, abundance SST allometric relationships, package permits estimating total energyscape species, spatialised energetic needs total population. Furthermore, energyscape can used combination diet composition prey energy content information estimate total biomass prey necessary top predator population sustain needs. package developed framework European Horizon 2020 Program EcoScope project, funded grant agreement number 101000302.

what: Estimating energyscape and biomass consumption — bio_cons_est
title: Estimating energyscape and biomass consumption — bio_cons_est
text: function first estimates energyscape (spatialised energetic need population) marine predator species (either cetacean, seabirds, loggerhead turtles, sunfish, sharks, tunas swordfish) abundance map body mass distribution, well sea surface temperature (fish ). Second, function estimate daily ration consumed given prey group single predator individual corresponding biomass consumed total population. Results provided maps vectors. function runs single estimation. Allometric relationships derived White et al. (2011) beta parameters Spitz et al. (2012) cetaceans; Ultsch et al. 2013 loggerhead turtle; Killen et al. (2016) fishes Shaffer et al. (2011) seabirds (contrasting Procellariforms Charadriforms).

title: Estimating energyscape and biomass consumption — bio_cons_est
code: bio_cons_est(   predator_group,   predator_name,   beta = NULL,   prey_taxonomic_level,   prey_group,   diet,   assimilation_rate = 0.8,   n_days = 1,   predator_weight,   abundance_map,   temperature_map = NULL )

title: Estimating energyscape and biomass consumption — bio_cons_est
text: predator_group Character. Predator taxonomic group, used select allometric equation used compute analysis. Can "Cetacean", "Fish", "Charadriform", "Procellariform", "Loggerhead turtle" predator_name Character. Name used exported dataframes beta Vector life cost parameter, used mammals prey_taxonomic_level Taxonomic level diet summarize (either "Family", "Taxonomic_group" "Functional_group", example), .e. column prey_group subsetted prey_group level diet select (one levels chosen prey_taxonomic_level) diet Diet table, including considered predator . Must include pW (proportion item diet, proportion wet weight), Energy_content prey item (kJ/g) column provided prey_taxonomic_group assimilation_rate Assimilation rate used estimate daily ration (default 0.8) n_days Number days estimating biomas consumption (default 1) predator_weight Vector body mass distribution predator (kg) abundance_map Abundance map predator (must provide columns named mean sd) temperature_map SST map (used fish; must provide columns named mean sd)

title: Estimating energyscape and biomass consumption — bio_cons_est
text: function returns list composed 6 elements: FMR, energetic needs single individuals (kJ/d); abundance, abubndance map; Energyscape, energyscape map total predator population, single day (FMR*abundance; kJ/d); daily_ration, estimated daily ration (kg); prop_body_mass, daily ration expressed proportion predator body mass; conso_map, map prey_group biomass consumed predator population period provided n_days.

title: Estimating energyscape and biomass consumption — bio_cons_est
code: result <- bio_cons_est(predator_group = "Cetacean",              predator_name = "TURTRU",               prey_taxonomic_level = "Taxonomic_group",               prey_group = "Cephalopoda",              diet = diet,               assimilation_rate = 0.8,              n_days = 30+31+31,              predator_weight = weight,               abundance_map = species_abundance,               temperature_map = sst,              beta = beta) # not used for fishes and seabirds

what: Estimating energyscape and biomass consumption with Monte Carlo simulations — mc_simulation
title: Estimating energyscape and biomass consumption with Monte Carlo simulations — mc_simulation
text: Function run Monte Carlo simulation energyscape biomass estimations. functions identifies prey levels defined prey_taxonomic_level, drop item pW Energy_content missing, runs bio_cons_est function n_sim times item, extracts posterior distributions estimated parameter returns summarized results levels prey_taxonomic_level.

title: Estimating energyscape and biomass consumption with Monte Carlo simulations — mc_simulation
code: mc_simulation(   predator_name,   predator_group,   map_coordinates,   beta = NULL,   prey_taxonomic_level,   diet,   assimilation_rate = 0.8,   n_days = 1,   predator_weight,   abundance_map,   temperature_map = NULL,   nsim = 1000 )

title: Estimating energyscape and biomass consumption with Monte Carlo simulations — mc_simulation
text: predator_name Character. Name used exported dataframes predator_group Character. Predator taxonomic group, used select allometric equation used compute analysis. Can "Cetacean", "Fish", "Charadriform", "Procellariform", "Loggerhead turtle" map_coordinates data.frame containing x y coordinates map beta Vector life cost parameter, used mammals prey_taxonomic_level Taxonomic level diet summarize (either "Family", "Taxonomic_group" "Functional_group", example), .e. column prey_group subsetted diet Diet table, including considered predator . Must include pW (proportion item diet, proportion wet weight), Energy_content prey item (kJ/g) column provided prey_taxonomic_group assimilation_rate Assimilation rate used estimate daily ration (default 0.8) n_days Number days estimating biomas consumption (default 1) predator_weight Vector body mass distribution predator (kg) abundance_map Abundance map predator (must provide columns named mean sd) temperature_map SST map (used fish; must provide columns named mean sd) nsim number simulations run; 1000 default

title: Estimating energyscape and biomass consumption with Monte Carlo simulations — mc_simulation
text: function returns list 8 elements: FMR_map, map FMR (kJ/d); Energyscape_map, energyscape map (kJ/d; FMR * abundance), abundance species (columns named N_); DailyRation_map, map daily ration (kg); DailyRationPropBM_map, proportion body mass; DailyRation, estimated daily ration averaged map (table; kg); DailyRationPropBM, proportion body mass; Conso_map, map total consumed biomass (kg) Conso, consumed biomass summed map (kg). one category exists prey_taxonomic_level, maps returned tables long format (directly usable facetting ggplot), except FMR Energyscape return maps estimated first category (two elements, result prey_group).

title: Estimating energyscape and biomass consumption with Monte Carlo simulations — mc_simulation
code: # test mc_simulation() with one prey level TURTRU_result <- mc_simulation(predator_name = "TURTRU",                                 predator_group = "Cetacean",              map_coordinates = map_coords,              prey_taxonomic_level = "Taxonomic_group",               diet = diet |> subset(Taxonomic_group == "Cephalopoda"),               assimilation_rate = 0.8,              n_days = 30+31+31,              predator_weight = weight,               abundance_map = species_abundance,               temperature_map = sst, # not used for cetaceans and seabirds              beta = beta)  # test mc_simulation() with 2 prey levels TURTRU_result <- mc_simulation(predator_name = "TURTRU",                                 predator_group = "Cetacean",              map_coordinates = map_coords,              prey_taxonomic_level = "Taxonomic_group",               diet = diet,               assimilation_rate = 0.8,              n_days = 30+31+31,              predator_weight = weight,               abundance_map = species_abundance,               temperature_map = sst, # not used for cetaceans and seabirds              beta = beta) #> Computing Teleost for TURTRU #> Computing Cephalopoda for TURTRU #> Wrapping up  # plot results ggplot2::ggplot(TURTRU_result$Conso) +     ggplot2::geom_pointrange(ggplot2::aes(y = Prey_category, x = mean, xmin = L10, xmax = U90))   ggplot2::ggplot(TURTRU_result$Energyscape) +   ggplot2::geom_tile(ggplot2::aes(x = x, y = y, fill = Energyscape_mean))
